thread.title_full: Post Office boss: The poor pay for free banking

title: Post Office boss: The poor pay for free banking
text:
0.00 
Nicholas Kennett says that overdraft fees are being used to offer free bank accounts to the wealthy 
Free bank accounts are unfair to poor customers and form an unsustainable foundation for the banking system, according to Post Office Money’s chief executive, Nicholas Kennett, who wants to see the industry charge customers regular fees instead . 
He believes it is unfair that customers who have to use their overdrafts are charged high fees, which are then used by the bank to offer free accounts to the better-off who rarely pay any fees. 
The system also makes it hard for new banks to challenge the incumbents, as the cross-subsidy makes it hard for customers to work out which account offers better value. 
The Competition and Markets Authority is expected to publish an interim report this month into the state of the personal current account market, which could include proposals for making it more competitive. 
“Our view is that the free-in-credit account structure with cross-subsidies between customer groups means that a large number of customers do not get a fair deal, and they are paying for other people’s accounts,” Mr Kennett said. 
“If you manage your money on a week-by-week or month-by-month basis, and consequently may need to go overdrawn or have a transaction refused, you are hit by quite significant fees and penalties. 
“Through that, you are subsidising people who may be able to manage their money better or who have a bit more money and so do not need to go overdrawn, who get the account for free and yet, that account is still costing a lot of money to service.” 
While this may mean that customers who never incur fees and charges are well-served, he argues that charging customers for the services they use would be fairer overall and lead to better service for more account-holders. 
In his case, the Post Office offers an account which costs £5 per month and will not let customers rack up unexpected overdraft fees. 
He also argues that the free accounts have led to mis-selling of products at other banks, with institutions keen to raise funds in other ways such as by selling PPI or packaged accounts, since they have had to cover the costs of providing free accounts to customers. 
More than a decade ago Mr Kennett spearheaded the Commonwealth Bank of Australia’s successful effort to revolutionise banking in that market, introducing a fee of two Australian dollars a month for accounts, while simplifying or scrapping other costs and fees. 
Other banks in Australia followed suit, and he believes it made the market fairer and more competitive, as customers now pay for what they use and can see how they are charged for each product. 
Other challenger banks have also complained about the free accounts making it difficult for them to crack the market. 
Paul Pester, the chief of TSB, has suggested banks put a bill at the end of each statement, detailing which services customers have received and what they have paid in the month, to make the overall costs and benefits clearer. 
Tesco Bank adds a line to statements showing customers how much interest they lost out on each month by keeping money in the current account rather than moving it into a savings account, which pays a better rate on balances (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
